entries.meaning: A shoot sprouting from the root of a cropped plant, especially sugar cane.
examples: Ratoons, probably so named from a corruption of the Spanish word brotones, are suckers and sprouts, that spring from the roots of canes that have previously been cut down.
Mr. Hawley did give me a little black rattoon, painted and gilt.

verbs.description: ratoon (third-person singular simple present ratoons, present participle ratooning, simple past and past participle ratooned)

entries.meaning: (intransitive, of a plant) To sprout ratoons.
examples: In the sugar areas to the north and south of the Colony cane has been known to "ratoon" for 20 to 30 years.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To cut a plant, especially sugar cane, so that it will produce ratoons.
examples: Attempts to propagate them by cuttings (of flowering shoots) and to ratoon the old plants in the greenhouse in November were unsuccessful.
